content:
It's clear that in some cases, like the toposes of:

  • reflexive globular sets
  • simplicial sets
  • plain cubical sets
  • cubical sets with diagonals and connections

you actually do get an "internal sublocale of levels" and it induces a(n essential) geometric surjection from the toposes of globular sets, semi-simplicial sets, plain semi-cubical sets, and semi-cubical sets with diagonals, respectively. However, in maximal generality it isn't clear to me either that meets distribute over joins, or that you even get a sheaf.
The standard reference for this is Kelly-Lawvere but their arguments don't seem to internalize easily, nor do they attack the problem of meets distributing over joins.

One issue making this difficult is that there does not seem to have been any intrinsic characterization discovered of the meets of essential subtoposes; they are known only in the form of the join of all mutual lower bounds of the arguments of the meet. This means that infinite distributivity depends on the "density" of essential subtoposes of E\mathcal{E}E and hence of orthogonal factorization systems in E\mathcal{E}E. (Essential subtoposes correspond to classes of morphisms that are the left class of one factorization system while being the right class of another!)

It seems that there actually is a "sheaf" Ess\it{Ess}Ess of essential subtoposes, at least, although I'm not sure it's small in general. The morphisms A→EssA \to \it{Ess}A→Ess are the essential subtoposes of E/A\mathcal{E}/AE/A.

Proof sketch (is a presheaf)

The functorial action of a presheaf on E\mathcal{E}E is given by a straightforward modification of Elephant A4.1.3. For a morphism f:A→Bf : A \to Bf:A→B and an essential embedding g:F→E/Bg : \mathcal{F} \to \mathcal{E}/Bg:F→E/B:

  • Inverse image on objects: h:C→A↦g∗(h):g∗(hf)→g∗(f)h : C \to A \mapsto g^*(h) : g^*(hf) \to g^*(f)h:C→A↦g∗(h):g∗(hf)→g∗(f), action on arrows is as g∗g^*g∗
  • Direct image is h:C→g∗(f)↦(ηfg∗∗)∗(g∗(h)):dom(g∗C×g∗(g∗(f))f)→Bh : C \to g^*(f) \mapsto (\eta^{g^*_*}_f)^*(g^*(h)) : \mathrm{dom}(g_*C \times_{g_*(g^*(f))} f) \to Bh:C→g∗(f)↦(ηfg∗∗​​)∗(g∗(h)):dom(g∗​C×g∗​(g∗(f))​f)→B, action on arrows uses the same formula
  • Essentiality is h:C→B↦ϵfg!∗∘g!(h)h : C \to B \mapsto \epsilon^{g_!^*}_f \circ g_!(h)h:C→B↦ϵfg!∗​​∘g!​(h), action on arrows is as g!g_!g!​
  • Importantly, the counit of the inverse-direct adjunction is h:C→g∗(f)↦ϵCg∗∗∘(g∗g∗(h))∗g∗(ηfg∗∗)h : C \to g^*(f) \mapsto \epsilon^{g^*_*}_C \circ (g^*g_*(h))^*g^*(\eta^{g^*_*}_f)h:C→g∗(f)↦ϵCg∗∗​​∘(g∗g∗​(h))∗g∗(ηfg∗∗​​). This is an isomorphism because ϵg∗∗\epsilon^{g^*_*}ϵg∗∗​ is a natural isomorphism and so is g∗ηg∗∗g^*\eta^{g^*_*}g∗ηg∗∗​ as the inverse of ϵg∗∗g∗\epsilon^{g^*_*}g^*ϵg∗∗​g∗, meaning we still land in embeddings.

Proof sketch (gluing in canonical topology)

(placeholder to keep these together in the unlikely case someone replies)

Proof sketch (smallness)

A Lawvere-Tierney topology on E/A\mathcal{E}/AE/A is determined by its underlying map j:Ω/A→Ω/Aj : \Omega_{/A} \to \Omega_{/A}j:Ω/A​→Ω/A​. But Ω/A\Omega_{/A}Ω/A​ is just the second projection of Ω×A\Omega \times AΩ×A. But this is a cofree object of the slice category on Ω\OmegaΩ so we have E/A(Ω/A,Ω/A)≅E(Ω×A,Ω)≅E(A,ΩΩ)\mathcal{E}/A(\Omega_{/A},\Omega_{/A}) \cong \mathcal{E}(\Omega \times A, \Omega) \cong \mathcal{E}(A, \Omega^\Omega)E/A(Ω/A​,Ω/A​)≅E(Ω×A,Ω)≅E(A,ΩΩ). Thus Ess\it{Ess}Ess is a subsheaf of ΩΩ\Omega^\OmegaΩΩ and is small.
What are those factorization systems where essential subtoposes show up? I think those are new to me.

I was referring to Theorem 3.2 of Kelly-Lawvere, which characterizes "essential reflective subcategories" in general, hence essential subtoposes in particular, as the full subcategories of objects right orthogonal to classes of morphisms E\mathscr{E}E such that there exist orthogonal factorization systems (E,M)(\mathscr{E},\mathscr{M})(E,M) and (N,E)(\mathscr{N},\mathscr{E})(N,E).

Peter Arndt said:

What are those factorization systems where essential subtoposes show up? I think those are new to me.

If Δ⊣Γ⊣∇:S→E\Delta\dashv\Gamma\dashv\nabla:S\to EΔ⊣Γ⊣∇:S→E is an "adjoint cylinder" between finitely complete and cocomplete categories (with Δ\DeltaΔ and ∇\nabla∇ fully faithful), the arrows that are inverted by Γ\GammaΓ are the left class of an OFS whose right class are the arrows whose unit-naturality-square for the Γ⊣∇\Gamma\dashv\nablaΓ⊣∇ adjunction is a pullback. Dually, the Γ\GammaΓ-inverted arrows are the right class of an OFS whose left class are the arrows whose counit-naturality-square for Δ⊣Γ\Delta\dashv\GammaΔ⊣Γ is a pushout.

For example, if Γ\GammaΓ is the forgetful functor from topological spaces to sets, the "middle" arrows are continuous maps which are bijective on points, the right maps are those where the domain topology is the initial topology wrt the codomain, and the left maps are those where the codomain topology is the final topology wrt the domain.
Cool, thanks!

I claim that for a Lawvere-Tierney topology jjj on a Grothendieck topos, the following are equivalent:

  1. jjj commutes with BBB-ary meets for any set BBB.
  2. BBB-th powers of the dense monomorphism classifier are dense for any set BBB.
  3. BBB-th powers of any dense monomorphism are dense for any set BBB.
  4. Every object has a smallest dense subobject in a nicely coherent way.
  5. Sheafification has a left adjoint.

As every open subtopos has its complementary closed subtopos, so every essential subtopos has a complementary reflective subcategory. Say fff is the inclusion of an essential subcategory in E\mathcal{E}E. Then f∗−1(1){f^*}^{-1}(1)f∗−1(1) is a reflective subcategory of E\mathcal{E}E; the reflector is given by the following pushout:

f!f∗A→ϵAf!f∗!↓↓ηf!f∗1→f&A\begin{CD} f_! f^* A @>{\epsilon}>> A \\ @V{f_! f^* !}VV @VV{\eta}V \\ f_! f^* 1 @>>> f_\& A \end{CD}f!​f∗Af!​f∗!↓⏐​f!​f∗1​ϵ​​​A↓⏐​ηf&​A​

where ϵ\epsilonϵ is the counit of the coreflector f!f∗f_! f^*f!​f∗ and η\etaη becomes the unit of the reflector f&f_\&f&​. These objects are "sheaves" in that they are local with respect to subobjects that include all the non-skeletal parts of an object; however the complementary closure operator (union with the skeleton) does not commute with arbitrary pullbacks and so the reflector is not left exact. (Or rather, when it is, it is the reflector for a closed subtopos and fff is open.)

I hope that, even though the lattice of arbitrary reflective subcategories of a topos is not itself very well-behaved, the existence of these complements (or maybe "complements") serves to regulate the behaviour of essential subtoposes.

@James Deikun Interesting! To make sure I understand correctly: in the case of the level nnn of simplicial sets, the complementary reflective subcategory would be the simplicial sets with exactly one simplex in all dimensions up to nnn?

That's exactly right! The entire thing parallels the discussion of closed subtoposes in A4.5.3 of the Elephant, with appropriate replacements (−×U- \times U−×U becomes the coreflector and E/U\mathcal{E}/UE/U becomes the coreflective subcategory of skeletal objects).
That's a very nice observation, I'm not aware of that appearing anywhere in the Lawverian "dialectical" interpretation of these things. Menni might now ...
But are you hoping that the lattice of essential sub-toposes might always be distributive? Have you tried finding counterexamples in simple presheaf toposes?

I kind of am hoping that, but even if it's not true I want to understand the boundaries of when it is true. You make a good point though; after putting this much time in without finding a general principle yet I should probably try giving more time to that kind of "experiment".

Are you aware of the characterization of essential sub-toposes in presheaf toposes in terms of idempotent "ideals" (Kelly-Lawvere, Thm 4.4)? I was thinking about similar things, and my next step would be to try to spell that out for some very simple index categories. I'm not even sure if the levels are always of presheaf type for finite, Cauchy-complete index categories?

They are for any finite index categories. The simplest example of a non-presheaf essential subtopos of a presheaf category I've come up with is presheaves on the poset of rational numbers, with strict inequality as the idempotent ideal.
Ahh, great! I'll have to think about that example.
